item.title: JSS Compiler Help
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

A compiler consists of (at the least) a lexer (lexical analyzer) which converts a character sequence into a stream of tokens, a parser which takes a stream of tokens and builds a concrete syntax tree, and an emitter that emits the concrete syntax tree nodes into an output format, which could be native object code, virtual machine bytecode, or even another language (these are usually called something like language converters or something).

Read full topic

item.title: JSS Compiler Help
item.dc:creator: @zstars zstars
item.description:
@zstars wrote:

Dynamic languages such as Javascript are kinda hard to compile to native, you might wanna switch language, or use a Javascript subset, or use some kind of bytecode (either an existing VM or your own). Also, you might wanna get some (e)book on compiler building, there are quite a few around.

Read full topic

item.title: JSS Compiler Help
item.dc:creator: @unlimitedorb unlimitedorb
item.description:
@unlimitedorb wrote:

Code generation is a fairly involved topic. I doubt anything enlightening is going to happen in this thread. That being said, don’t emit directly to bytecode or platform dependent machine code. Research three-address code and/or static single assignment form.

Just pick up a good book on compiler theory or implementation and run with it. Compilers: Principles, Techniques, and Tools (the purple dragon book) is extremely well written, but it’s also very long. If you’re in it for the long haul, I highly suggest reading it (I only got about halfway, but I have every intention of finishing it later on haha). There are other books that go into far more depth, but they’re usually domain specific. I’ve been told there are better introductory books, but I can’t vouch for any of them seeing as I haven’t read them. You can probably find something better, but I can almost guarantee you that the Purple Dragon book will be in the bibliography.

Read full topic

item.title: JSS Compiler Help
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

oksuper_:

yours can’t be better than mine seeing as both do the same thing, you fucking retard.

really? so because both of out libraries supposedly accomplish the same task (which isnt completely true) it means that there cant be one that is better? ive seen many phones that accomplish same tasks (call, send sms, browse web) but there are features that overcome the other one’s (signal strength, etc)

not only does mine never spit out an error during runtime, causing it to crash (like yours), it also has a (very small) beginning to the implementation of instruction parsing

[quote=“oksuper_, post:17, topic:305356”]PS mine doesn’t crash ‘for anything’, maybe if you had an ounce of intelligence in your thick skull you would notice that.[/quote]oh really? yours doesnt crash when attempting to parse a (relatively) large class file (by this i mean around > 70 KB or so (dont know the exact size that causes it to crash but something around there)). therefore, since yours sometimes doesnt even accomplish its task, and mine does…ALWAYS, mine is better than yours

[quote=“oksuper_, post:17, topic:305356”]you WANT people to appreciate your work, which explains why you are telling him to look at yours or suggesting it as an easier alternative (just like mopar and cherokee)[/quote]i am suggesting him to take a look at the library that accomplishes something that he will need in the future (if he ends up compiling into java bytecode), the library is an already existent implementation of it

[quote=“oksuper_, post:17, topic:305356”]but the truth is you didn’t do anything worth appreciating. maybe next time you should post something worth looking at.[/quote]in that case, ditto to you. according to you, our libraries were equal (which is not true), so if they were, they are both ‘worth the same appreciation’

Read full topic

item.title: JSS Compiler Help
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

Since you’re finding it too hard, why not choose an easier language

en.wikipedia.org

Brainfuck

Brainfuck is an esoteric programming language created in 1993 by Urban Müller, and notable for its extreme minimalism. The language consists of only eight simple commands and an instruction pointer. While it is fully Turing complete, it is not intended for practical use, but to challenge and amuse programmers. Brainfuck simply requires one to break commands into microscopic steps. The language's name is a reference to the slang term brainfuck, which refers to things so complicated or unusual t...

Read full topic

item.title: JSS Compiler Help
item.dc:creator: @inertia inertia
item.description:
@inertia wrote:

I’m trying to make a compiler in JavaScript but am having a few problems with the language.

The source files are of JSS type (JavaScriptSource)(MIME:text/jss), which I will show you in a sec.

I have completed semantic and lexical analysis of the source, along with basic preprocessing but the problem lies with generating the final code for the program. The code generated will simply be readable by the native os of the system the compiler is running on because I cba to make it portable, but I’m having trouble programming the processing which decides which variables to fit into registers and memory and the selection and scheduling of appropriate machine instructions along with their associated addressing modes.

This is an example of The JSS Source Code Example:

importulate pckgs.jss.io.*;
  using eJaculationPeriod "8" std:
    object run [
      mOut = fresh{call io.mOut};
      mOut({"Hello World!"});
      mOut({CLOSE});
    ][term({})]
    object term [
      mOut({"io.mOut error"});
    ]
  :;

Any ideas?

Read full topic
